sentences.sentence: By StÃ©phane SÃ©rafin, Kerry Sun and Xavier Foccroulle MÃ©nardTwo opinion articles on Section 1 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms have now been published in the National Post in as many weeks.

In the first op-ed, Arjun Singh argued(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/arjun-singh-left-wing-values-have-invaded-canadas-legal-system-and-diminished-our-charter-rights) that Section 1, which permits such "reasonable limits" to guaranteed rights "as can be demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society," had been used as a pretext to allow "left wing values" to undermine the absolute nature of the rights at issue.

In the second op-ed, lawyer Andrew Bernstein responded(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/andrew-bernstein-canadas-legal-system-has-not-been-invaded-by-the-left-wing-our-charter-has-ensured-that) that section 1 had not been used to illegitimately curtail Charter rights, but instead represents "a compromise between two essential parts of our constitutional structure: individual rights and democratic self-government.
"Yet both of these perspectives on the Charter are, if not incorrect, then incomplete.
That constitutional rights and freedoms should be absolute in the broad, unbounded sense advocated by Singh is not only an incoherent idea, but practically unworkable.

All legal orders seek to delimit the scope of legal rights, whether by narrowly construing the right itself, as in American constitutional law, or by employing a "limitations clause" like Section 1 of the Canadian Charter.The problem with Bernstein's view, however, is that it appears to confuse two very different mechanisms found in the Charter that allow judges or legislators to make determinations as to the scope of the protected rights: Section 1, the "reasonable limits" clause; and Section 33, the "notwithstanding clause."
Indeed, Bernstein is correct to note that the Charter represents a compromise between individual rights and democratic government.
But he attributes the fulfillment of this compromise to the wrong section of the Charter.
More than Section 1, it is in reality the notwithstanding clause that can properly be said to "preserve our essential democratic character."

Section 33 allows Parliament or a provincial legislature to express disagreement with the interpretation of Charter rights favoured by a court in a particular case, and instead to adopt its own preferred view, consistent with its democratic mandate.

As the Supreme Court of Canada explained in the 1998 Vriend case, disputes over the meaning of rights and the justification of their limits are inevitable and "the role of the judiciary enters to resolve these disputes," but "S. 33, the notwithstanding clause, establishes that the final word in our constitutional structure is in fact left to the legislature and not the courts."

By definition, democratic government is government by the people exercised through elected representatives, and the decision to invoke Section 33 is left to our elected representatives.Andrew Bernstein: Canada's legal system has not been 'invaded' by the left wing.

Our Charter has ensured that(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/andrew-bernstein-canadas-legal-system-has-not-been-invaded-by-the-left-wing-our-charter-has-ensured-that)Arjun Singh: Left wing values have invaded Canada's legal system and diminished our charter rights(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/arjun-singh-left-wing-values-have-invaded-canadas-legal-system-and-diminished-our-charter-rights)In contrast, as presently conceived, Section 1 is a mechanism of judicial balancing of rights limitations, conducted by courts through the Oakes test.
It is, however, at best a simulacrum for the democratic deliberation occurring in legislatures, owing most notably to the very institutional limitations of courts.

The court process is adversarial: it must always be initiated by an interested party, and no matter the number of interveners (third parties that make legal arguments to assist a court) allowed to participate, litigation remains a bilateral dispute, between two parties or sets of parties defending adverse propositions.
Courts are well-placed to make determinations in this kind of setting, including for the purpose of determining whether a particular individual's rights have in fact been infringed.
But they are not well-positioned to make the kinds of determinations that are truly implied in the phrase "democratic self-government."

This should not be a surprise, for in Canada, judges simply have a different role and mandate than elected representatives.This brings us to an alternative understanding of Section 1, and back to Singh's original argument.
If this clause permits limitations of Charter rights, then how should we comprehend those limits?

The answer, in short, is that Section 1 is less a means of balancing individual rights against the collective will expressed by a legislature, and more a recognition that all Charter rights possess internal limits.

In referring to "reasonable limits," Section 1 affirms the simple truth that the scope and content of rights must fall within reason: unbounded, expansive assertions of rights that are not amenable even to reasonable limits are, in a sense, not rights at all for they are opposed to what is right.

In other words, it calls for courts to determine whether a legislature has reasonably specified the scope of a right, given the interests and values pertaining to a particular context.On this reading, far from deserving to be abolished, Section 1 ensures that Charter rights remain tethered to the constraints of reason, which animates the system of rights in the Canadian legal order.Special to National PostStÃ©phane SÃ©rafin is Assistant Professor, Faculty of Law, Common Law Section, University of Ottawa.
Kerry Sun is a graduate of the University of Toronto, Faculty of Law.
Xavier Foccroulle MÃ©nard is a graduate of McGill University, Faculty of Law and the University of Toronto, Faculty of Law.
